moves: 1. c4 Nf6 2. Nc3 g6 3. g3 Bg7 4. Bg2 O-O
comment: A key question for White now is how does he intend to use Bc1 and where does he expect the fight to occur. If he wishes to stay within English Opening lines then he might delay a bit with d2-d3, but if he intends e2-e3, Ng1-e2, d2-d4 then that wouldn't do. If he intends e2-e4, d2-d3, Ng1-e2, h2-h3, Bc1-e3, Qd1-d2 then that choice has to be made within the next move or two. If he is interested in switching to a Regular King's Indian Defense with d2-d4 then he could delay a move, but not much longer. It's not the easiest choice to make because Black hasn't already committed his central and queen-side pawns & pieces to any particular formation (a goal of the KID) and Black will usually endeavor to choose the set-up which best challenges whatever White starts with.

moves: 1. c4 Nf6 2. Nc3 g6 3. g3 Bg7 4. Bg2 O-O 5. d4
comment: It's interesting that this position for White can just as easily be played against a Tarrasch Defense or a Queen's Indian Defense or a Benko Gambit.

moves: 1. c4 Nf6 2. Nc3 g6 3. g3 Bg7 4. Bg2 O-O 5. d4 d6 6. Nf3 Nc6
comment: Shirov has been playing this move (Panno) against the Saemisch Variation too (with mixed results) .

moves: 1. c4 Nf6 2. Nc3 g6 3. g3 Bg7 4. Bg2 O-O 5. d4 d6 6. Nf3 Nc6 7. O-O a6
comment: The general idea appears to be to expand on the queen-side to pressure the weak Pc4, though at this early point Black might even have in mind ...e5 and ...Nd4.

moves: 1. c4 Nf6 2. Nc3 g6 3. g3 Bg7 4. Bg2 O-O 5. d4 d6 6. Nf3 Nc6 7. O-O a6 8. Re1 Na5 9. Qa4 b6
comment: This move might just be a way of defending Na5 without committing to ...c5 (yet) , but it could also be a way of offering a light square bishop trade by ...Bc8-b7 (if White opens the diagonal further) .

moves: 1. c4 Nf6 2. Nc3 g6 3. g3 Bg7 4. Bg2 O-O 5. d4 d6 6. Nf3 Nc6 7. O-O a6 8. Re1 Na5 9. Qa4 b6 10. Nd5
comment: This is probably over-reaching and Black's play will show that soon.

moves: 1. c4 Nf6 2. Nc3 g6 3. g3 Bg7 4. Bg2 O-O 5. d4 d6 6. Nf3 Nc6 7. O-O a6 8. Re1 Na5 9. Qa4 b6 10. Nd5 Bd7 11. Qc2 c5
comment: Black had no intention of playing ...Nxd5 to allow White cxd5, securing control of c6 and removing Pc4 as a target.

moves: 1. c4 Nf6 2. Nc3 g6 3. g3 Bg7 4. Bg2 O-O 5. d4 d6 6. Nf3 Nc6 7. O-O a6 8. Re1 Na5 9. Qa4 b6 10. Nd5 Bd7 11. Qc2 c5 12. Nxf6+
comment: Helping to uncover Bg7 can't be recommended.

moves: 1. c4 Nf6 2. Nc3 g6 3. g3 Bg7 4. Bg2 O-O 5. d4 d6 6. Nf3 Nc6 7. O-O a6 8. Re1 Na5 9. Qa4 b6 10. Nd5 Bd7 11. Qc2 c5 12. Nxf6+ Bxf6 13. Bh6 Re8 14. e3
comment: Around 1920 this would have seemed to be a pretty good flexible way to develop without committing to d4-d5 and without giving up on a2-a3 and b2-b4. However, the truth is that Black is targeting White's central pawns and it's not so easy for White to get away from that defensive task to do something aggressive. Occupying the center has it's down-side.

moves: 1. c4 Nf6 2. Nc3 g6 3. g3 Bg7 4. Bg2 O-O 5. d4 d6 6. Nf3 Nc6 7. O-O a6 8. Re1 Na5 9. Qa4 b6 10. Nd5 Bd7 11. Qc2 c5 12. Nxf6+ Bxf6 13. Bh6 Re8 14. e3 Rc8 15. d5 b5
comment: Black trades one way of attacking Pc4 for another; Bf6 is also more open, though White might soon evacuate the dark square diagonal altogether.

moves: 1. c4 Nf6 2. Nc3 g6 3. g3 Bg7 4. Bg2 O-O 5. d4 d6 6. Nf3 Nc6 7. O-O a6 8. Re1 Na5 9. Qa4 b6 10. Nd5 Bd7 11. Qc2 c5 12. Nxf6+ Bxf6 13. Bh6 Re8 14. e3 Rc8 15. d5 b5 16. Nd2 Nxc4 17. Nxc4 bxc4 18. Bf1 Rb8 19. Rab1 Qa5 20. Rec1 Qxa2 21. Bxc4 Qa5
comment: So, Black has won a pawn and has the b-file with Bf6 piling on Pb2. How can it be so easy for Black to achieve such a terrific position? This is an excellent example of the hyper-modern style of play (for Black) .

moves: 1. c4 Nf6 2. Nc3 g6 3. g3 Bg7 4. Bg2 O-O 5. d4 d6 6. Nf3 Nc6 7. O-O a6 8. Re1 Na5 9. Qa4 b6 10. Nd5 Bd7 11. Qc2 c5 12. Nxf6+ Bxf6 13. Bh6 Re8 14. e3 Rc8 15. d5 b5 16. Nd2 Nxc4 17. Nxc4 bxc4 18. Bf1 Rb8 19. Rab1 Qa5 20. Rec1 Qxa2 21. Bxc4 Qa5 22. b3
comment: Keeping up the approach it would seem Black could trade Pa6 for Pb3 and win a pawn ending because of Pc5, but much comes before that ending. Actually Black has to avoid simple trades because they might give White enough room to create some counter-play. Fortunately he has Bf6 to prevent White from occupying a1 with a rook. So, Black piles up on Pb3 and just tries to win in astraight-forward manner. Doubling rooks on the b-file is also likely.

moves: 1. c4 Nf6 2. Nc3 g6 3. g3 Bg7 4. Bg2 O-O 5. d4 d6 6. Nf3 Nc6 7. O-O a6 8. Re1 Na5 9. Qa4 b6 10. Nd5 Bd7 11. Qc2 c5 12. Nxf6+ Bxf6 13. Bh6 Re8 14. e3 Rc8 15. d5 b5 16. Nd2 Nxc4 17. Nxc4 bxc4 18. Bf1 Rb8 19. Rab1 Qa5 20. Rec1 Qxa2 21. Bxc4 Qa5 22. b3 Bb5
comment: If Black trades bishops at c4 and White has to recover with a pawn then Black will have a passed Pa6 and Pc4 will still be weak.

moves: 1. c4 Nf6 2. Nc3 g6 3. g3 Bg7 4. Bg2 O-O 5. d4 d6 6. Nf3 Nc6 7. O-O a6 8. Re1 Na5 9. Qa4 b6 10. Nd5 Bd7 11. Qc2 c5 12. Nxf6+ Bxf6 13. Bh6 Re8 14. e3 Rc8 15. d5 b5 16. Nd2 Nxc4 17. Nxc4 bxc4 18. Bf1 Rb8 19. Rab1 Qa5 20. Rec1 Qxa2 21. Bxc4 Qa5 22. b3 Bb5 23. e4 Rb7 24. Bd2 Qa3 25. Re1 Reb8 26. Bc1 Qa5 27. Bd2 Qc7 28. Re3 Qd7
comment: Heading for the open h3 square or just backing up Bb5?

moves: 1. c4 Nf6 2. Nc3 g6 3. g3 Bg7 4. Bg2 O-O 5. d4 d6 6. Nf3 Nc6 7. O-O a6 8. Re1 Na5 9. Qa4 b6 10. Nd5 Bd7 11. Qc2 c5 12. Nxf6+ Bxf6 13. Bh6 Re8 14. e3 Rc8 15. d5 b5 16. Nd2 Nxc4 17. Nxc4 bxc4 18. Bf1 Rb8 19. Rab1 Qa5 20. Rec1 Qxa2 21. Bxc4 Qa5 22. b3 Bb5 23. e4 Rb7 24. Bd2 Qa3 25. Re1 Reb8 26. Bc1 Qa5 27. Bd2 Qc7 28. Re3 Qd7 29. Rc1 Bd4
comment: Now Re3 goes on a strange journey.

moves: 1. c4 Nf6 2. Nc3 g6 3. g3 Bg7 4. Bg2 O-O 5. d4 d6 6. Nf3 Nc6 7. O-O a6 8. Re1 Na5 9. Qa4 b6 10. Nd5 Bd7 11. Qc2 c5 12. Nxf6+ Bxf6 13. Bh6 Re8 14. e3 Rc8 15. d5 b5 16. Nd2 Nxc4 17. Nxc4 bxc4 18. Bf1 Rb8 19. Rab1 Qa5 20. Rec1 Qxa2 21. Bxc4 Qa5 22. b3 Bb5 23. e4 Rb7 24. Bd2 Qa3 25. Re1 Reb8 26. Bc1 Qa5 27. Bd2 Qc7 28. Re3 Qd7 29. Rc1 Bd4 30. Rf3 Qg4 31. Rf4 Qh5 32. Rh4 Qe5
comment: White finds it difficult to defend all his weak spots: Pb3, Bc4 and Pe4.

moves: 1. c4 Nf6 2. Nc3 g6 3. g3 Bg7 4. Bg2 O-O 5. d4 d6 6. Nf3 Nc6 7. O-O a6 8. Re1 Na5 9. Qa4 b6 10. Nd5 Bd7 11. Qc2 c5 12. Nxf6+ Bxf6 13. Bh6 Re8 14. e3 Rc8 15. d5 b5 16. Nd2 Nxc4 17. Nxc4 bxc4 18. Bf1 Rb8 19. Rab1 Qa5 20. Rec1 Qxa2 21. Bxc4 Qa5 22. b3 Bb5 23. e4 Rb7 24. Bd2 Qa3 25. Re1 Reb8 26. Bc1 Qa5 27. Bd2 Qc7 28. Re3 Qd7 29. Rc1 Bd4 30. Rf3 Qg4 31. Rf4 Qh5 32. Rh4 Qe5 33. Rb1 Bxc4 34. Qxc4 f5
comment: Black is smashing White's position into tiny little bits, but he has to be a little careful not to expose Kg8 to some incidental counter-attack.

moves: 1. c4 Nf6 2. Nc3 g6 3. g3 Bg7 4. Bg2 O-O 5. d4 d6 6. Nf3 Nc6 7. O-O a6 8. Re1 Na5 9. Qa4 b6 10. Nd5 Bd7 11. Qc2 c5 12. Nxf6+ Bxf6 13. Bh6 Re8 14. e3 Rc8 15. d5 b5 16. Nd2 Nxc4 17. Nxc4 bxc4 18. Bf1 Rb8 19. Rab1 Qa5 20. Rec1 Qxa2 21. Bxc4 Qa5 22. b3 Bb5 23. e4 Rb7 24. Bd2 Qa3 25. Re1 Reb8 26. Bc1 Qa5 27. Bd2 Qc7 28. Re3 Qd7 29. Rc1 Bd4 30. Rf3 Qg4 31. Rf4 Qh5 32. Rh4 Qe5 33. Rb1 Bxc4 34. Qxc4 f5 35. Re1 Rxb3 36. exf5 Qxf5 37. Rf4 Qd3
comment: Forcing a queen trade would end any hope White had of creating a surprise attack on Kg8. That would leave Black's superior rooks and passed pawns to win the game.
